TopicTitle: [0.23.5] Spherical and Toroidal Tank Pack (Updated 05/02/14) (New download link)

darn bbcodes

Just popping in here to say that I've been watching this discussion and it is fascinating. I am learning much, but don't have the background to add anything substantial to the conversation. That being said:

I will now go back to the drawing board and rework the torus masses and volumes (even that looks a little iffy to me).

I'll finally do the official update when you have the chance to do this As always, I appreciate your l337 math sk1llz

Well, here I disagree with you. You can use ropes, they're very capable if you need to support something heavy.

In general, agreed. I'm talking about these tanks .

Anyway, using KSP stock tank wall mass densities (ick, but it's either match or fix every tank, and that's RF's job), it looks like the toroidal tanks will have a mass ratio of 3.64. Still pretty bad, but better than TO-S-1's. I Think I'll up it by changing some assumptions about the internal designs of the tanks: make use of the space in that bicycle rim on the tanks and in the arms. I already have them hollow (to cut down on dry mass), so might as well use the space, though the ratio will never get all that high.

OK, I've done my homework...

I won't bother with screenshots, but I will describe what I've done. First, I determined the intended size of the base toroidal tank model (as used for the large tank, as it turns out): major radius 3m, minor radius 0.5m. This gives a torus volume of Vreal=14.804m3 (this will be used later on.

I then edited the model by deleting all non-visible parts, moving the "arms" (and hoops) and the tank section itself apart (for ease of working). I cleaned up the tank part (tire plus rim if thought of as a bicycle wheel), made sure it was all manifold (ie, no openings) and used blender's volume tools to get Vouter=14.409m3. I added a solidify modifier with a thickness of 0.009 (9mm) and got a volume of Vshell=0.509m3. Subtracting gives Vinner=13.900m3.

It was then that I realized this was too far out from a real tank of such design (it would be smooth curves rather than faceted), so I cleaned up the tank to be just a torus shape (ie, deleted anything outside the 0.5m minor radus and filled in the holes). For this I got Vfake=13.976m3 (no solidify modifier). I figured that "close enough is good enough" and just used the ratio of the real and fake volumes to scale everything. Thus...


V[sub]tank[/sub]   =V[sub]shell[/sub]*(V[sub]real[/sub]/V[sub]fake[/sub]) =  0.509*14.804/13.976 =  0.5392m[sup]3[/sup]
V[sub]contents[/sub]=V[sub]inner[/sub]*(V[sub]real[/sub]/V[sub]fake[/sub]) = 13.900*14.804/13.976 = 14.7235m[sup]3[/sup]

I did similar shenanigans with the arms (and hoops), but didn't bother with any correction factors. I capped the ends to get the total volume (0.183m3), remove the caps and added a 9mm solidify modifier to get the pipe shell volume (Vpipe=0.069m3) and subtracted to get Varm=0.114m3.

Thus:


V[sub]t[/sub]=V[sub]tank[/sub]+V[sub]pipe[/sub]=0.5392+0.069=0.6082
V[sub]c[/sub]=V[sub]contents[/sub]+V[sub]arm[/sub]=14.7235+0.114=14.8375

The scales (as best I can tell) are, from small to extra-large: 0.25, 0.625, 1, 1.5. Thus, using a density of 7.8t/m3 for the shell...


Name    Capcity   Shell  Dry Mass
TO-S-1   0.2318  0.0095   0.0741
TO-M-1   3.6224  0.1485   1.1582
TO-L-1  14.8375  0.6082   4.7440
TO-XL-1 50.0766  2.0527  16.0109

Capacity and Shell are in m3, Dry Mass is in tons. Shell is given only for independent verification .

All tanks have an LFO wet/dry mass ratio of 4.128 (lousy, but that's geometry for you). If you want a better mass ratio, talk to NathanKell (he'll give you titanium alloy tanks:cool:).

[edit]D'oh: forgot to add the tank mass to the fuel mass for the ratio (3.128->4.128)

Officially updated to v3.11 with the updated models and taniwha's dry mass figures

v3.11

- Updated models, should fix issues with tanks resizing when used as root node

- Updated dry masses of toroidal tanks. (Thanks again to taniwha for the maths)

I am having a issue with modifying the contents of the tanks in v.23 as well. I noticed that the tool-tip I get in game only talks about the colors and does not discuss the alternate fuels that the tank can support (as indicated in the OP picture). It also says LF xxx.xxx (x = quantity) and Oxidizer xxxx.xxx on the tool-tip. When I switch to action groups and select the tank, no new windows or icons appear anywhere on my screen. I have installed several different tanks with the exact same outcome each time. I am also using the tanks found under the propulsion tab and not the tanks found under utilities.

When I installed I took the two folders and copied them into the GameData directory.

Do you have the Modular Fuel Tanks mod installed? That's required in order to be able to change the fuel types, but is not included in the pack. Without it you'll be limited to the LiquidFuel and Oxidizer.

I just downloaded and installed it, but the OP doesn't specifically state that you need to have this plugin installed for it to work. No matter though thank you for pointing that out to me.. Now for another failed return attempt from duna lol.

Do the "structural" versions of the tanks have any use in the stock game? I can't transfer fuel or anything into them.

The reason he doesn't include it is so people can pick modular or realfuels, and the tanks work on their own don't they without either if you just want Fuel+LOX?

This is the case. Another issue that comes up is if they update MFT, then having an old version included with my download can cause more issues. The tanks are if fact set up to default to LF+O if modular fuels or realfuels isn't installed. This way people won't have to wait on me to update the pack every time NathanKell or taniwha update their respective plugins. It will just work with their updates automatically.

I will, however, add links to their respective threads on the OP and ensure that it is more clear that their plugin will be required to get the modular fuels functionality. I understand the frustration of having to download additional mods, and that's why I initially included the plugin with the download, but differing development cycles makes it very hard to keep everything on the same page all the time, so separate downloads is really the best way to go.

This pack enables some interesting lander designs btw:
